review.title: A Sentence Meaning Based Alignment Method for Parallel Text Corpora Preparation
review.abstract: Text alignment is crucial to the accuracy of Machine Translation (MT) systems, some NLP tools or any other text processing tasks requiring bilingual data. This research proposes a language independent sentence alignment approach based on Polish (not position-sensitive language) to English experiments. This alignment approach was developed on the TED Talks corpus, but can be used for any text domain or language pair. The proposed approach implements various heuristics for sentence recognition. Some of them value synonyms and semantic text structure analysis as a part of additional information. Minimization of data loss was ensured. The solution is compared to other sentence alignment implementations. Also an improvement in MT system score with text processed with described tool is shown.

metadata.title: A Sentence Meaning Based Alignment Method for Parallel Text Corpora Preparation

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Before a parallel corpus can be used for any processing, the sentences must be aligned. Sentences in the raw corpus are usually misaligned, with translation lines whose placement does not correspond to the lines of text in the source language. In addition, some sentences do not need to be translated at all. The corpus may also contain bad or indirect translations, making alignment difficult. Thus, alignment with many systems is crucial for accuracy. It is a very complicated West Slavic language with complex elements and grammatical rules to use in different applications.

sections.heading: 2 Literature Overview
sections.text: Early attempts to automatically align sentences for parallel corpora were based on sentence lengths, along with vocabulary adjustments [19]. Brown's method [20] was based on measuring sentence length based on the number of words. Gale and Church [21] measured the number of characters in sentences. Other researchers continued to research various methods of combining sentence length statistics with vocabulary adjustments [22, 23]. Several text aligners are currently available to implement these methods, including Bleualign, an open source project developed by the University of Zurich. In addition to parallel texts, Bleualign requires the translation of a text. It uses the length-based bilingual comparison metric (BLEU) to align the texts [11]. The Hunalign tool is another open source tool developed by the Media Research Center. Based on Gale and Church's method, it uses sentence lengths and optional alignment of texts into two languages.

sections.heading: 4 Sentence Alignment Metric
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point where it is only a matter of time before a result is achieved.

sections.heading: 5 Comparison Experiments
sections.text: The Polish data in the Translanguage English Database (TED) lectures (approx. 15 MB) comprise over 2 million words without tokenicity, and the additional aligners, all created to develop parallel corpora, were used in this experiment: Bleualign, Hunalign, ABBYY Aligner, Wordfast Aligner and Unitex Aligner. Aligner performance was evaluated using the sentence alignment metric described in Section 3. Table 2. The first three aligners performed well. The proposed method is fully automatic. It is important to note that Bleualign text is not translated and requires it to be executed manually. As discussed above, it is important not to lose lines of text in the alignment process.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In general, sentence alignment algorithms are very important for the creation of parallel text corpora. Most aligners are not fully automated, but the one proposed here is what gives it a distinct advantage. It also enables the creation of a corpus when sentences exist only in a single language. The proposed approach is also language independent for those with a structure similar to PL or EN.The results show that the proposed method performed very well in terms of metrics. Unlike the other aligners, it also did not lose any lines of text, which is crucial to the end goal of getting a translated text. Our alignment method has also proven to be better in comparison with typical machine translation metrics and would most likely improve the output quality of MT systems.
